docs.lead_paragraph: Property taxes have been reduced for nine homeowners here because they live near a halfway house for former psychiatric patients. The unusual ruling by the Board of Tax Review has enraged advocacy groups for the mentally ill and has prompted the threat of a civil-rights suit by the State Attorney General. The homeowners, after unsuccessfully seeking to prevent the halfway house from opening last year, were able to convince the board that property values on their block were likely to suffer and that their assessments should be reduced. ''If there's nothing wrong with the halfway house,'' said Pat Biase, who has lived on the block all of his life, ''why don't they put it next to the Greenwich Country Club?''

headline.main: TAXES CUT FOR NEIGHBORS OF HOME FOR MENTALLY ILL
